Title: Cortical connections of visual area MT in the macaque.

"Although Maunsell and Van Essen (1983) appear to have included FST within MST, there are several reasons for distinguishing between the two areas." (p. 199)
"Although Maunsell and Van Essen (1983) appear to have included FST within MST, there are several reasons for distinguishing between the two areas." (p. 199)
"As shown in Fig. 15, MT projects to two areas, VIP and MST, that are located within area PG (Bonin and Bailey, 1947)..."
"As shown in Fig. 15, MT projects to two areas, VIP and MST, that are located within area PG (Bonin and Bailey, 1947)..."
"It is not clear whether VIP* overlaps with area LIP of Andersen et al. (1985)..."

"The lateral, heavily myelinated portion of VIP (VIP*) appears to fall within the internal division of area POa (POa-i) of Seltzer and Pandya (1980). POa-i runs the full length of the sulcus, however, and is therefore considerably larger than VIP*." (p. 218)

"The organization of the dorsomedial prestriate cortex imediately anterior to dorsal V2 and V3d is somewhat unclear at present...at its medial end lies PO (Covey et al., 1982)...The upper visual field representation of PO lies on the medial aspect of the hemisphere, adjacent to the lower visual field representations of V2 and V3d, while the lower field representation of PO lies more laterally, mainly in the parieto-occipital sulcus adjacent to V3A and area 5 (Covey et al., 1982)." (p. 198)

"The only additional projection found in this case...was a projection to PO, an area that receives projections from the peripheral representations of other visual areas (Colby et al., 1983)." (p. 192)

"V2 was identifiable in myelin-stained sections...The correspondence between V2 and a distinctive myeloarchitectural zone was first established in the macaque by Gattas et al. (1981) on the basis of electrophysiological mapping. In hematoxylin-stained sections, Gattas et al. described V2 as having a uniform pattern of myelination in the lower cortical layers. In sections stained with silver by the Gallyas (1979) method, we have seen additional myeloarchitectural detail in V2..." (p. 196)

"Newsome et al. (1980) and more recently Van Essen et al. (1986) have suggested the term VP for the portion of V3 on the ventral surface of the hemisphere because of similarities with area VP in the owl monkey. We prefer the terms V3d and V3v for the dorsal and ventral portions of V3, respectively, because a homology between V3v and VP has not yet been shown." (p. 196)

"Newsome et al. (1980) and more recently Van Essen et al. (1986) have suggested the term VP for the portion of V3 on the ventral surface of the hemisphere because of similarities with area VP in the owl monkey. We prefer the terms V3d and V3v for the dorsal and ventral portions of V3, respectively, because a homology between V3v and VP has not yet been shown." (p. 196)
"As Maunsell and Van Essen (1983) have previously termed this MT projection zone VIP, we have followed their terminology."

"Most of VIP is characterized by heavy myelination...It remains a possibility...that the two myeloarchitectural regions actually correspond to two separate areas. Therefore, to distinguish the heavily myelinated portion of VIP from the remainder, we will refer to the former as VIP*." (p. 199)
"VIP may also overlap with area POa of Seltzer and Pandya (1980) which was defined on the basis of architecture..."

"Zeki (1973, 1977, 1978b) originally described the 'V4 complex' as the cortex on the prelunate convexity that lies between V3, V3A, and MT...In our companion study (Desimone and Ungerleider, 1986) we distinguished within Zeki's original V4 complex a separate area, V4t, which is a narrow area bordering MT." (p. 198)

"Zeki (1973, 1977, 1978b) originally described the 'V4 complex' as the cortex on the prelunate convexity that lies between V3, V3A, and MT...In our companion study (Desimone and Ungerleider, 1986) we distinguished within Zeki's original V4 complex a separate area, V4t, which is a narrow area bordering MT." (p. 198)

"Zeki (1973, 1977, 1978b) originally described the 'V4 complex' as the cortex on the prelunate convexity that lies between V3, V3A, and MT...In our companion study (Desimone and Ungerleider, 1986) we distinguished within Zeki's original V4 complex a separate area, V4t, which is a narrow area bordering MT." (p. 198)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: To avoid misunderstandings: the reference "Zeki 1978b" in the text equals Z78c in this database.

"The lateral, heavily myelinated portion of VIP (VIP*) appears to fall within the internal division of area POa (POa-i) of Seltzer and Pandya (1980). POa-i runs the full length of the sulcus, however, and is therefore considerably larger than VIP*." (p. 218)

"The organization of the dorsomedial prestriate cortex imediately anterior to dorsal V2 and V3d is somewhat unclear at present...at its medial end lies PO (Covey et al., 1982)...The upper visual field representation of PO lies on the medial aspect of the hemisphere, adjacent to the lower visual field representations of V2 and V3d, while the lower field representation of PO lies more laterally, mainly in the parieto-occipital sulcus adjacent to V3A and area 5 (Covey et al., 1982)." (p. 198)

"The only additional projection found in this case...was a projection to PO, an area that receives projections from the peripheral representations of other visual areas (Colby et al., 1983)." (p. 192)

"V2 was identifiable in myelin-stained sections...The correspondence between V2 and a distinctive myeloarchitectural zone was first established in the macaque by Gattas et al. (1981) on the basis of electrophysiological mapping. In hematoxylin-stained sections, Gattas et al. described V2 as having a uniform pattern of myelination in the lower cortical layers. In sections stained with silver by the Gallyas (1979) method, we have seen additional myeloarchitectural detail in V2..." (p. 196)

"As Maunsell and Van Essen (1983) have previously termed this MT projection zone VIP, we have followed their terminology."

"Most of VIP is characterized by heavy myelination...It remains a possibility...that the two myeloarchitectural regions actually correspond to two separate areas. Therefore, to distinguish the heavily myelinated portion of VIP from the remainder, we will refer to the former as VIP*." (p. 199)
"VIP may also overlap with area POa of Seltzer and Pandya (1980) which was defined on the basis of architecture..."

"Zeki (1973, 1977, 1978b) originally described the 'V4 complex' as the cortex on the prelunate convexity that lies between V3, V3A, and MT...In our companion study (Desimone and Ungerleider, 1986) we distinguished within Zeki's original V4 complex a separate area, V4t, which is a narrow area bordering MT." (p. 198)

publication.title: Cortical connections of visual area MT in the macaque.
